definitions: utter a loud sharp cry expressing fear pain or excitement
make a loud high-pitched sound like a cry
be extremely or glaringly obvious or conspicuous in appearance
examples: She screamed when she saw the spider crawling
The children screamed with joy at the playground
The brakes screamed as the car came to halt
The wind screamed through the broken window all night
The headlines screamed the shocking news across the page
Her bright pink dress screamed for attention at the party

definitions: make a loud harsh piercing cry or sound
come to a sudden halt with a harsh grinding noise
examples: The owl screeched in the darkness outside our window
She screeched at him to stop immediately
The car screeched to a halt at the red light
The train screeched to a stop at the platform

definitions: examine someone or something systematically to assess suitability or detect problems
show or broadcast a film television program or other media
protect conceal or shelter someone or something from view or harm
pass something through a sieve or filter to separate elements
examples: The hospital screens all patients for infectious diseases
Security personnel screen passengers before boarding flights
The theater will screen the new movie tonight
The documentary was screened at the film festival
The tall trees screen the house from the road
She screened her eyes from the bright sunlight
They screen the sand to remove rocks and debris
The machine screens grain to separate different sizes

definitions: take a digital image capture of what is displayed on a computer or device screen
examples: Please screenshot the error message for tech support
I screenshot the conversation as evidence of the agreement

definitions: attach or fasten something using a screw by rotating it
turn or twist something with a rotating motion
damage mess up or ruin something through incompetence or mistake
cheat exploit or treat someone unfairly especially in business
examples: He screwed the shelf brackets firmly to the wall
She carefully screwed the lid back onto the jar
Screw the cap tightly to prevent any leaks
He screwed the parts together following the instructions
I really screwed up the presentation this morning
Don't screw this opportunity by being late
The company screwed their employees out of bonuses
He got screwed in that business deal

definitions: write or inscribe something carefully especially in an official capacity
mark or score a surface with a pointed tool for cutting or decoration
examples: The clerk scribed the details into the official ledger
Monks would scribe manuscripts by hand for centuries
The carpenter scribed a line on the wood before cutting
She scribed her initials into the wet cement

definitions: engage in a practice game or informal match especially in team sports
engage in a confused struggle or rough physical contest
examples: The football team will scrimmage against each other today
The players scrimmaged for two hours during practice
The kids scrimmaged over the last piece of cake
Protesters and police scrimmaged in the street

definitions: write the text dialogue or screenplay for a performance or broadcast
plan arrange or predetermine events or responses in advance
examples: She scripted the entire television series by herself
The playwright scripted a brilliant adaptation of the novel
The interview questions were carefully scripted in advance
They scripted every detail of the ceremony

definitions: move text or images up down or across a computer display screen
roll up a length of paper parchment or other flexible material
move slowly and steadily past or through an area or view
examples: Scroll down to find the information you need
She scrolled through hundreds of photos on her phone
He carefully scrolled the ancient manuscript for storage
The students scrolled their diplomas after the ceremony
The credits scrolled past on the movie screen
Clouds scrolled across the evening sky

definitions: clean something thoroughly by rubbing hard typically with a brush and soap
cancel abort or abandon a planned event or mission
remove unwanted or sensitive data information or elements from something
examples: She scrubbed the kitchen floor until it sparkled
He scrubbed his hands thoroughly before the surgery
NASA had to scrub the launch due to weather
They scrubbed the mission at the last minute
The agency scrubbed all classified data from the report
Engineers scrubbed the code to remove bugs

definitions: move quickly and smoothly in a straight line especially driven by wind
examples: Dark clouds scudded across the stormy sky
The sailboat scudded before the strong wind

definitions: engage in a short confused fight or struggle at close quarters
examples: The two boys scuffled in the playground over a toy
Police scuffled with protesters outside the building

definitions: propel a boat using sculls which are light oars used in pairs
examples: She sculled her boat across the calm lake
The team sculled in perfect synchronization during practice

definitions: create a three-dimensional work of art by carving or shaping materials
shape form or alter something to achieve a desired appearance or effect
examples: The artist sculpted a beautiful statue from marble
She sculpts primarily with clay and bronze
Exercise helped sculpt his body into better shape
The wind sculpted the sand into graceful dunes

definitions: make or create sculptures as an artistic practice or profession
examples: She sculptures full-time in her downtown studio
He has been sculpturing for over twenty years

definitions: form a layer of dirt froth or foam on top of a liquid
examples: Algae scummed the surface of the stagnant pond
The soup scummed over as it cooled down

definitions: move quickly with short hurried steps often in a nervous manner
examples: Mice scurried across the kitchen floor at night
People scurried to get out of the rain

definitions: run with quick short steps especially in a hurried or furtive manner
deliberately sink a ship by making holes in the bottom or opening seacocks
deliberately cause a plan or undertaking to fail or be abandoned
examples: The crab scuttled sideways across the sand
She scuttled away when she saw her ex-boyfriend
The captain ordered the crew to scuttle the ship
They scuttled their vessel rather than surrender
Opposition members tried to scuttle the trade agreement
Bad weather scuttled our plans for a picnic

definitions: cut grass grain or crops with a scythe using a sweeping motion
examples: The farmer scythed the wheat field by hand
He scythed through the tall grass with practiced strokes

definitions: fasten or close something securely to prevent access or leakage
apply an official seal or stamp to authenticate or certify a document
confirm finalize or make definite an agreement decision or outcome
examples: She sealed the envelope before mailing the letter
Workers sealed the crack to prevent water damage
The notary sealed the legal document with her stamp
Officials sealed the contract with the company emblem
The victory sealed their place in the championship
They sealed the deal with a firm handshake

definitions: join two pieces of fabric or material together with a line of stitching
examples: She carefully seamed the dress panels together
The tailor seamed the jacket with invisible stitches

definitions: travel in or pilot a seaplane aircraft designed to take off and land on water
examples: They seaplaned to the remote island resort
The pilot seaplaned tourists around the tropical archipelago

definitions: burn or scorch the surface of something with sudden intense heat
cause a sudden sharp stinging pain or strong unpleasant feeling
examples: The chef seared the steak in a hot pan
Heat from the fire seared his exposed skin
The bitter wind seared their faces during the climb
The memory of failure seared into his mind

definitions: try to find something or someone by looking carefully and thoroughly
examine a place person or thing thoroughly to find something or someone
examples: She searched everywhere for her missing keys
Police searched for clues at the crime scene
Security searched all bags at the entrance
Investigators searched the suspect's apartment yesterday

definitions: add salt pepper herbs or spices to food to enhance its flavor
treat or prepare wood or other material to improve its properties
make someone experienced or accustomed through exposure over time
examples: Season the chicken with salt and pepper before cooking
She seasoned the soup with fresh herbs from the garden
The wood must season for months before use
They seasoned the cast iron pan with oil
Years of travel had seasoned him as a diplomat
Combat experience seasoned the young soldiers quickly

definitions: arrange for someone to sit down in a particular place or position
have seats or space for a specified number of people
fit fix or install something firmly in its proper position
examples: The usher seated us in the third row
Please seat yourself wherever you feel comfortable
The theater seats five hundred people comfortably
This restaurant seats about forty guests
The mechanic properly seated the valve in the engine
Make sure the gasket is seated correctly

definitions: formally withdraw from membership in a political union alliance or organization
examples: Several southern states seceded from the Union in 1861
The province threatened to secede from the federation

definitions: formally support or endorse a motion or proposal in a meeting
temporarily transfer someone to a different job department or organization
examples: I second the motion to adjourn the meeting
Will anyone second this proposal for consideration
The company seconded her to the Paris office
He was seconded to the military advisory team

definitions: produce and discharge a substance from cells or glands in the body
hide or conceal something in a secret place to keep it hidden
examples: The pancreas secretes insulin to regulate blood sugar
These glands secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream
He secreted the stolen diamonds in a hidden compartment
She secreted the letter away in her diary

definitions: divide something into separate parts or segments for organization or analysis
cut through something especially biological tissue for microscopic examination
examples: The architect sectioned the building into different zones
They sectioned the report into five main chapters
The pathologist sectioned the tissue sample for analysis
Scientists sectioned the brain for detailed study

definitions: make something safe from threat danger or loss through protective measures
succeed in obtaining or achieving something desired often with effort
fix or fasten something firmly so it cannot move or be removed
examples: They secured the building with new locks and alarms
The firewall secures the network from cyber attacks
She secured funding for her research project
The team secured victory in the final minutes
Secure the rope tightly to the anchor point
Workers secured the cargo before the ship departed

definitions: administer sedative drugs to make someone calm or unconscious for medical purposes
examples: The veterinarian sedated the injured animal for treatment
Doctors sedated the patient before the surgical procedure

definitions: settle to the bottom of a liquid as particles or matter forming a deposit
examples: Sand and silt sediment at the river bottom
Particles slowly sedimented in the still water

definitions: entice someone into sexual activity through charm or persuasion
persuade someone to do something inadvisable or foolish through temptation
attract someone strongly with an appealing or tempting quality
examples: He tried to seduce her with expensive gifts and flattery
The character seduces multiple people throughout the novel
Don't let gambling seduce you into financial ruin
Power can seduce even the most principled leaders
The beautiful scenery seduced us into staying longer
She was seduced by the glamour of city life

definitions: perceive with the eyes or have the power of sight
understand realize or become aware of something through thought or observation
meet or spend time with someone socially or professionally
experience witness or live through an event or period
make sure of something by checking or taking action
examples: I can see the mountains from my window
She sees better with her new glasses
I see what you mean about the problem
He finally saw the truth about the situation
The doctor will see you at three o'clock
She sees her parents every weekend
Our company has seen tremendous growth this year
He lived to see his grandchildren graduate
See that all doors are locked before leaving
I'll see what I can do to help

definitions: plant or sow seeds in soil for growing plants or crops
remove seeds from fruit or vegetables before eating or cooking
assign a ranking position to players or teams in a tournament
examples: They seeded the lawn with grass in early spring
Farmers seed their fields after the last frost
Please seed the tomatoes before adding them to salad
She seeded the peppers for the sauce
The committee seeded the teams based on past performance
She was seeded third in the tennis tournament

definitions: try to find or discover something by searching or questioning
attempt to obtain or achieve something through effort or request
ask for advice help or assistance from someone
examples: Scientists seek answers to complex questions about nature
Police are seeking witnesses to the accident
Many graduates seek employment in technology companies
The organization seeks donations for its programs
She sought advice from her mentor about careers
Patients often seek second opinions from specialists

definitions: give the impression of being something or having a particular quality
examples: She seems happy with her new job
The task seemed impossible at first glance

definitions: flow or leak slowly through porous material or small openings
examples: Water seeped through the cracks in the basement wall
Oil seeped into the ground from the damaged tank

definitions: move up and down or back and forth on or as on a seesaw
change repeatedly from one state condition or position to another
examples: Children seesawed happily in the playground all afternoon
The boat seesawed on the rough waves
Stock prices seesawed throughout the trading day
Public opinion has seesawed on this issue

definitions: divide something into separate parts or sections for analysis or organization
examples: Marketing teams segment customers into different demographic groups
The documentary segments the story into three parts

definitions: separate or divide people or things into different groups based on characteristics
isolate or separate someone or something from others for specific purposes
examples: The school illegally segregated students by race
They segregate waste into recyclable and non-recyclable bins
The hospital segregates infectious patients from other wards
Prison officials segregated the violent inmates

definitions: make a smooth and uninterrupted transition from one thing to another
examples: The speaker segued from economics into environmental policy
The band segued perfectly from one song to the next

definitions: catch fish using a seine net that hangs vertically in water
examples: Fishermen seined for salmon in the coastal waters
They seine the river every morning for fresh catch

definitions: take hold of suddenly and forcibly with hands or arms
take control or possession of something by force or authority
affect someone suddenly and powerfully with emotion or sensation
take possession of property by legal authority or warrant
examples: He seized her arm to prevent her from falling
The dog seized the stick in its teeth
Rebels seized control of the government building
The army seized power in a military coup
Fear seized him as he entered the dark room
A sudden pain seized her chest
Police seized illegal drugs during the raid
Customs officers seized the contraband shipment

definitions: carefully choose someone or something as being the best or most suitable
examples: The committee selected three finalists for the position
She selected the perfect gift for her mother

definitions: give or hand over something in exchange for money
persuade someone to accept or approve of an idea or proposal
be purchased by customers or have commercial success in the market
examples: She sells handmade jewelry at the local market
They sold their house for a good price
He managed to sell the idea to investors
Can you sell this proposal to the board
These products sell well during the holidays
Her books sell millions of copies worldwide

definitions: send signals or messages using flag positions or mechanical arms
examples: The scout semaphored a message to the camp
Ships semaphored warnings to each other in fog

definitions: cause someone or something to go to a particular destination
transmit a message signal or communication to someone
cause something to move rapidly or forcefully in a direction
examples: She sent her son to the store for milk
They send packages worldwide through their service
I'll send you an email with the details
The station sends signals to satellites in orbit
The explosion sent debris flying in all directions
The news sent shockwaves through the community

definitions: perceive something through one or more of the physical senses
detect or become aware of something without obvious signs
understand or realize something through intuition rather than conscious reasoning
examples: She could sense the aroma of fresh coffee brewing
The blind man sensed objects through touch
The dog sensed danger before anyone else
I sense tension in the room
She sensed that something was wrong immediately
He sensed her disappointment without her saying anything
